item.title: Hamline’s Bullying Prevention Certificate
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Hamline University’s Bullying Prevention Certificate is an online multicourse program designed to provide adults with the knowledge, skills, and resources for creating safe learning environments for children. By participating in this program, students will have the opportunity to learn about bullying prevention through a series of cutting-edge courses developed by the program coordinator and Nationally Certified Bullying Prevention Specialist, Cheryl Green. Read more.

item.title: History of Special Education and IDEA
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
Passed in 1975, The Education for All Handicapped Children Act (later updated and renamed the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act) guaranteed every child a free and appropriate education. Prior to the enactment of this law, many children with disabilities were denied an education and often lived in state institutions. This law initiated federal funding for special education and has resulted in progress towards designing effective programming to educate children with disabilities. This law, now called the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), has undergone several revisions over the years and most recently in 2004. IDEA guarantees special education and related services to eligible students with disabilities through age 21, including preparation for employment and independent living for students 14 and older. There are 13 specific categories of disability under IDEA: autism spectrum disorders, deaf-blind, deaf and hard of hearing, developmental cognitive disability, developmental delay, emotional or behavior disorders, other health disabilities, physically impaired, severely multiply impaired, specific learning disability, speech or language impairments, traumatic brain injury, and visually impaired. We suggest reading this interesting article on the history of IDEA and the connection to racial civil rights.
Did you know? In Minnesota, children can receive services under “developmental delay” until they reach age 7. Then they must qualify for services under one of the other 13 categories.

IDEA 2004

IDEA 2004 is a very large, extensive document and is 162 pages long. Here are some key provisions:

FREE APPROPRIATE PUBLIC EDUCATION (FAPE)

Every child is entitled to a free and appropriate public education and related services. However, this doesn’t mean it has to be the best education. The term “appropriate” is subject to individual interpretation, and it is the responsibility of the IEP team to determine what services will meet the unique needs of each student.

LEAST RESTRICTIVE ENVIRONMENT (LRE)

Children with disabilities must be educated in an environment that meets their unique needs alongside their peers without disabilities to the maximum extent possible. Consideration must be given to modifications that can be made to accommodate the student’s individual needs, allowing them to remain in the least restrictive setting in which they can succeed. Optional settings to the general education classroom must be made available to meet the needs of the student; however, these settings do not need to be available at every school in the district. This placement must be reviewed at least once per year by the IEP team.

CHILD FIND

Public school districts are responsible for locating, identifying, and evaluating all children with disabilities in their districts who need special education or related services, whether they are attending public or private schools. This is accomplished through Child Find activities.

DISCIPLINE

The disability of a student must be taken into account with regard to disciplinary action. Stay Put – is the right of a student to remain in their current special education placement and continue to receive services while any disputes between the parents and school district are being resolved, unless parents and the school district both agree to the change. There are exceptions to this rule for weapons and drug offenses. If the student is facing more than 10 consecutive days out of school, Stay Put gives each student the right to remain in the current placement while alleged violations of school code are determined. There is an exception to the Stay Put rule for weapons and drug offenses. Parents* who feel their child’s educational rights have been compromised can file a complaint with the school district within two years of the dispute. The school district has 30 days to resolve the issue to the satisfaction of the parents before a due process hearing can occur. Complaints determined to be frivolous can result in parents paying attorney costs incurred by the school district. See section on Conflict Resolution. *"Parents" will be used for brevity, but includes "Parents/Guardians."

INDIVIDUALIZED EDUCATION PROGRAM

The public schools must create an Individualized IEP Program (IEP) for qualifying students. This is a written document that is designed to meet the unique needs of each student receiving special education services and related services. There are several steps to determine eligibility. For more details on IDEA, view the IDEA Parent Guide from the National Center for Learning Disabilities.

item.title: Conflict Resolution
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
If you have a conflict with the school district regarding your child's education, there are several ways to come to a resolution.

DISCUSS YOUR CONCERNS WITH THE CASE MANAGER

Sharing your concerns with your child’s case manager can be a simple and quick way to resolve differences.

IEP TEAM MEETING

Call a meeting with the IEP team and attempt to work out an agreement regarding your concerns.

CONTACT THE SPECIAL EDUCATION DIRECTOR

Another option is to contact the special education director from your school district (the special education director oversees the special education department). You can find out who the special education director for your school district is here.

FACILITATED IEP MEETING

If parents and school districts are having difficulty writing the IEP, an impartial facilitator (not part of the IEP team) can help with the process and assist with any disagreements. Like mediation, this service is provided by the Minnesota Department of Education’s Mediation Service (MNSEMS) and is free of charge. For more information:
  • PACER Center: Facilitated IEP Meetings
  • The Arc Greater Twin Cities: Arc Guide to a Facilitated IEP Meeting

RESOLUTION OR CONCILIATION MEETING

Established by IDEA 2004, a resolution meeting is a way to resolve conflicts. A resolution meeting must be held within 15 calendar days of receiving a notice of due process unless parents choose not to participate or choose mediation instead. If a resolution is not achieved, the 45-day timeline for due process starts the next day. Resolution meetings are provided at no cost to parents. Information on conciliation from PACER Center can be found here.

MEDIATION

Mediation is an option for parents to resolve conflicts in lieu of a formal due process hearing. In addition to the IEP team members, a neutral third party called a mediator joins the meeting to help the parents and school district come to an agreement. The process is voluntary and both the parents and school district must agree to mediate. If agreed to by both parties, a meeting should be held within 2 to 4 weeks. The Minnesota Department of Education’s Mediation Service (MNSEMS) helps families work out their differences using mediation. There is no charge for this service. For further information: Arc Guide to Special Education Mediation.

DUE PROCESS HEARING

If parents have a disagreement with the school district regarding their child’s education, they have a right to exercise their due process rights. Due process, specified under IDEA, gives parents a way to solve conflicts with the school district. These services are available for students who have IEP’s as well as younger children on an IFSP or those using an IIIP. A written complaint must be filed within two years of the dispute. Parents and school district meet with a hearing officer to present their positions regarding the disagreement. The hearing officer then makes a decision, based on the law. Parents must pay attorney fees and witness costs, but they may recover these costs if they are successful in the due process hearing. To initiate a special education due process hearing you must complete a Due Process Hearing Request Notice from the Minnesota Department of Education.

MORE INFORMATION

Radtke Education Law Radtke Education Law focuses on educating parents about their rights regarding special education and working with them to negotiate for special education and related services in advance of filing for due process. They also provide information services to help parents stay on top of breaking school issues and proactively manage their relationships with teachers and administrators. Division of Compliance and Assistance Special Education Complaint and Hearing Search Engine The Minnesota Department of Education (MDE) Complaint and Hearing Search Engine allows searches by keyword, case number, case type, issue and school district.

item.title: The IEP Process
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
It's important to identify, evaluate and serve students who need special education services. There is a 9-step process to ensure students, whose disabilities affect their ability to learn, receive a free appropriate public education.

THE 9 STEPS OF THE IEP PROCESS

STEP 1: Referral

When a parent suspects their child may have a disability that impacts their education, they can request a special education evaluation by the school district. A referral can also be made by school district staff. Under child find, each state is required to identify and evaluate students who may need special education or related services. Parents must give written permission for the initial evaluation and for any tests that will be used. If the school district refuses to conduct the evaluation, parents must be informed of this decision and of their rights regarding the school district’s refusal.

STEP 2: Evaluation

Once the request is received, a qualified team from the school district has 15 days to create an assessment plan and 30 school days to complete the evaluation. The 30 school days begins when the school receives a parent’s signature on the initial assessment plan. Information is gathered from a variety of sources that will help to identify the student’s educational needs. An accurate and thorough assessment is essential in determining if a student qualifies for services. The evaluation looks at a student’s strengths and difficulties in various areas of development and may include a combination of tests, parent observations and medical information.

STEP 3: Determine Eligibility

Once the evaluation is complete, parents meet with school staff to discuss the results. Based on the findings of the evaluation, a determination is made by the IEP team if the student meets the requirements for eligibility for special education and related services as defined by IDEA.
  • If the student is deemed not eligible for services by the school district and the parents agree, a possible option for modifications and accommodations is available for qualifying students under Section 504.
  • If the student is deemed not eligible for services by the school district and the parents disagree, they can request an Independent Educational Evaluation (IEE). This is completed by someone not employed by the school district, and the school district must pay for the IEE or show why the original evaluation was appropriate at an impartial due process hearing.
  • If the student is deemed eligible for services by the school district and the parents agree, a meeting is scheduled with the IEP Team within 30 days. The meeting must be scheduled at a time and place that is mutually agreed to by the school district and the parents.

STEP 4: Schedule IEP Meeting

A meeting time and place is scheduled that is mutually agreed to by the school district and parents. If the school district is unable to get parents to attend, they can hold the meeting without the parents if they have written evidence to show they made an appropriate effort to invite them. Alternative ways to allow parents to participate, such as by telephone, should be considered. Who Attends? These people should attend every meeting:
  • The parents/guardians
  • The student is always invited and should attend if it would be beneficial to them. This decision is usually made by the parents.
  • The special education teacher
  • If the student spends time in the regular education classroom, then the regular education teacher should attend. If the student has more than one teacher, the parents can ask for other teachers to come if they feel their attendance would be helpful, but usually one regular education teacher attends.
  • An administrative representative, other than the student’s teacher, who can make decisions on behalf of the school district
  • If the student was assessed for the first time, someone from the evaluation team must attend who can explain the results.
  • Anyone who will be providing services
Others can attend, depending on the needs of each student:
  • A specialist who can share information on how the student learns
  • Someone with special knowledge of Assistive Technology (AT) if this is a need of the student
  • A person who can clarify language and/or cultural needs of the student and family
  • Other individuals that the school district or parents feel have knowledge or expertise to share with the team about the student
Preparing for an IEP meeting with school staff:
  • Request a copy of the evaluation so you can review it prior to the meeting. Because there is so much information to be shared, it is easy to forget valuable questions or points – so write them down to bring with you.
  • Make a list of your child’s strengths and interests as well as challenges that affect learning. Think about what educational goals you would like to see your child attain over the next year.
  • Review previous IEPs and make note of successes as well as goals you feel your child has not made reasonable progress attaining in the previous year.
  • Allow adequate time for the meeting. Ask team members if they have any time constraints that would require them to leave early.
  • If possible, obtain a copy of the Procedural Safeguards before the meeting so you have a chance to review it. You will be asked to sign a form saying you received the Procedural Safeguards and were given the opportunity to ask questions regarding them.

Step 5: Hold IEP Meeting and IEP is Written

For students 3-21: An Individualized Education Plan (IEP) is developed and written by the IEP Team. Parents are equal members of the IEP team, along with school district staff. For students birth to 3: An Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP) is used instead of an IEP. An IFSP is broader and contains goals that focus on the child and involves the family. Services are usually provided in the child’s natural setting, instead of a school setting. See section on Individualized Family Service Plans. Beginning July 2003, a third option called an Independent Interagency Intervention Plan (IIIP) is an option for students through age 21 that use multiple state agencies. The IIIP reflects the collaboration of the school district, the county and state programs the student is currently using. Parents have a right to refuse the IIIP and can use an IEP or IFSP if they are under the age of 3. Read more about The Individualized Education Program (IEP) Read more about The Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP)

Step 6: Services are Provided

When an IEP is proposed, parents have 14 calendar days to agree or disagree in writing. If the IEP team agrees on special education and related services and the parents sign the IEP document, the student will begin receiving services. All of the school staff involved with the student will receive a copy of the IEP and each is responsible for providing their services listed in the document. You do not need to sign the IEP document at the time of the meeting. Advocacy groups recommend bringing a copy home to review. If you do not agree with contents of the IEP, you have options to resolve these differences. See section on Conflict Resolution.

Step 7: Progress Reports

Progress is measured periodically to check if the student is making adequate gains towards achieving annual goals. Progress reports for children receiving special education must be given to parents at least as frequently as their peers without disabilities.

Step 8: Annual IEP Review

Each student’s IEP is reviewed at least once per year. Parents can, however, ask for an IEP meeting at any time if they have concerns about their child’s progress, placement, etc.

Step 9: Three-Year Reevaluation

At least every three years, a reevaluation is completed to determine if the student still qualifies for special education and related services. The reevaluation will also determine the student’s current educational needs. A reevaluation can be requested more frequently by any member of the IEP team.

item.title: The Individualized Education Program (IEP)
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
The IEP is an extremely important document. It contains information regarding a student’s academic, functional, social, and behavior needs and how the school district will assist in helping the student make gains in these areas of need. It is critical that the IEP accurately reflects the student’s current educational capabilities as well as challenges. The look of the IEP Document can change over time as revisions are made to the form, and each school district can decide what their form will look like. PACER Center has prepared A Guide For Minnesota Parents to the Individualized Education Program, which explains the sections of the IEP document. Although the look of the IEP form can change, all IEP’s contain identifying information about the student and parents, the primary disability category, and a list of IEP team members in attendance, along with the following:

PRESENT LEVELS OF ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND FUNCTIONAL PERFORMANCE (PLAAFP)

A PLAAFP is a summary of the student’s strengths and needs derived from evaluation and progress reports. Definitions of terminology highlighted in Green Italics can be found in the right sidebar. It describes how the student is doing now academically and functionally and how their disability affects their ability to learn. It can include information gained from test scores, reports from parents and teachers, and progress notes from previous IEPs.

ANNUAL GOALS AND SHORT-TERM OBJECTIVES

Annual goals are developed from the PLAAFP, and they should be attainable within one school year. They should be written using positive language, i.e., “the student will walk in the hallway,” instead of “the student will not run in the hallway.” Short term objectives or benchmarks are smaller steps that need to be met in order to achieve each annual goal.
  • National Autism Resources explains that well-written IEP goals should be SMART: Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant and Timely.

SPECIAL EDUCATION AND RELATED SERVICES

Detailed information regarding what service will be provided, when it will be provided, by whom it will be provided, where it will be provided, and how long it will be provided is listed for each special education and related service. If a student requires a paraprofessional, their responsibilities should be clearly described. Related Services are supportive services that assist a student in meeting goals and objectives. These are not a regular part of the school day for other students. Examples of related services are: occupational therapy, physical therapy, speech and language therapy, developmental adapted physical education (DAPE), transportation, music therapy, therapeutic recreation, and counseling services. Related services are provided by qualified staff and may be assisted by paraprofessionals. Related services are provided at no cost to parents; however, school districts can ask parents about Third Party Billing to cover costs of services that are medically related. See section on Third Party Billing. There are two types of services: direct services and indirect services. Direct services are provided to the student (or several students) directly. Indirect services support the student, but the staff does not work directly with the student.

LEAST RESTRICTIVE ENVIRONMENT

Students need to be taught in the general education classroom unless their specific needs require that they be placed in a more restrictive setting. A more restrictive setting is time spent away from typical peers. The IEP should state where services will be provided and are dependent on what the student’s individual needs require in order to be successful. Students should be taught in the least restrictive setting that allows them to make progress towards meeting their annual goals.

PROGRESS REPORTING

Students receiving special education services must have their progress measured and reported at least as often as their peers without disabilities. These reports should be specific so parents will know if their child is making adequate gains towards reaching their annual goals. The IEP states the frequency that progress reports will be reported to parents.

EXTENDED SCHOOL YEAR

Extended School Year (ESY) services are special education and related services that are available to students who will regress significantly if services are not continued during school breaks. Qualifying students receive ESY services at no charge, and transportation is provided. Determination if a student requires ESY services are made by the IEP team. Issues that are considered include regression and recoupment:
  • Regression involves the loss of skills that would occur over a school break without ESY services.
  • Recoupment is the amount of time that is needed to regain skills lost over a school break.
Minnesota law requires ESY services for students that would incur significant regression on IEP goals over school breaks and would require more time than the school break to recoup the loss of these skills. ESY services are not the same as summer school. For more information on an extended school year, see PACER Center's article "What does it mean? Could it be an option for your child?"

TRANSITION SERVICES

Goals related to independent living, postsecondary education and employment are required for students during grade 9 or at age 14.

TRANSFER RIGHTS AT AGE OF MAJORITY

When a student reaches 18 years old, legal rights are transferred to the student unless a guardian or conservator has been appointed. See section on Entering Adulthood.

STATE AND DISTRICT-WIDE ASSESSMENTS

Describes how or if modifications and adaptations are needed in order for the student to participate in state and district-wide assessments or if the student will be exempt due to their disability. If the student will not participate, an explanation of why the assessment is not appropriate for the student must be explained.

item.title: The Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP)
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
An Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP) is a document that details early intervention services for children from birth to age 3 that qualify for services through Part C of IDEA. It is also the process of finding, evaluating and providing services for young children with disabilities. The IFSP process is centered around and offers support to the child and his/her family.

WHO SHOULD BE REFERRED FOR SERVICES?

  1. A child, under three, having a diagnosed physical or mental condition or disorder with a high probability of resulting in a delay (regardless if the child is currently demonstrating a need or delay).
  2. A child, under three, who has a developmental delay in one or more of the following areas: cognitive, physical, communication, social/emotional or adaptive development
  3. A child, under three, whose parent or other person is concerned about a young child’s development.

WHAT IS THE EVALUATION PROCESS?

A child is referred for an evaluation by a parent, a professional currently working with the child, or by the school district through an Interagency Early Intervention Committee (IEIC). The IEIC is mandated by IDEA to identify and evaluate young children that are suspected of having a developmental disability or developmental delay. Members of the IEIC team include parents of children with disabilities, representatives from the school and county, and local service providers.
  • After receiving the referral, the school district has 45 calendar days to complete the evaluation. They must also complete the IFSP and begin services for children that qualify within this time period. If the school district has difficulty completing the evaluation within 45 days due to exceptional circumstances, they can ask parents for permission to develop an interim IFSP while they work on finishing the evaluation.
  • The team collects information about the child in areas of cognitive, physical, social/emotional, communicative and adaptive development, and evaluates fine motor skills, gross motor skills, and overall health. A multidisciplinary team will use observation, testing and interviews to gather information about the child. Since an IFSP is family focused, additional information is gathered regarding the family’s concerns and personal goals they have for their child
  • An IFSP meeting is held with parents, other interested family members, the service coordinator and those involved in completing the evaluation, and results of the evaluation are discussed. Parents can request a copy of the evaluation prior to review prior to the meeting.
  • If the evaluation determines that the child qualifies for services, an IFSP will be written and services will begin.
  • If the parents feel that the evaluation is not an accurate reflection of their child, they can request an Independent Education Evaluation (IEE) be obtained. An IEE is paid for by the school district unless they can prove their original evaluation was correct. See section on Independent Education Evaluations for more information.
  • If the evaluation determines that the child does not qualify for services, parents can exercise their due process rights. See section on Conflict Resolution.

WHAT IS INCLUDED IN THE IFSP DOCUMENT?

  • An explanation of the child’s present levels of academic and functional performance (PLAAFP) and why services are needed.
  • The family’s resources, priorities and concerns regarding their child’s development.
  • Goals the service providers will be working towards, along with how progress in achieving these goals will be measured and the frequency these services will be delivered.
  • Services unique to the needs of each child and their family and may include: assessment and evaluation, assistive technology, family training and counseling, nursing services, nutrition, occupational therapy, physical therapy, psychological services, respite, service coordination, social work, special instruction, speech therapy, transportation and vision services.
  • Who will provide the services? A service coordinator is assigned to the family to make sure the services in the IFSP are being provided and coordinates services between the family and other providers.
  • Where the services will be provided. Under IDEA, early intervention services should be provided in the child’s natural environment – where they typically would be during the day. This is usually in the home, but can be at a child care center, preschool or other location that the team chooses.
  • When the services will be provided. The need for year-round services is determined by the needs of the child and the family. Services from the school district are provided at no cost; however, services through interagency services may require a fee.

WHAT HAPPENS WHEN MY CHILD TURNS THREE?

When the child reaches age three, they will no longer be served by Part C of IDEA and will be evaluated under Part B of IDEA. If he/she qualifies, a meeting will be held to discuss the transition process from an IFSP to an Individualized Education Plan (IEP). The location services are delivered will change from the home to the least restrictive environment (LRE) in a school setting. Services under an IEP are not as broad as under an IFSP, and the focus is on special education and related services. See section on The Individualized Education Program for more information. If the child does not qualify under Part B, parents have options for an appeal. See section on Conflict Resolution. Early Childhood Connection, a newsletter from PACER Center and is a good resource for parents of children receiving early childhood services under an IFSP.

item.title: Independent Education Evaluation (IEE)
item.dc:creator: connectwc

item.title: Third-Party Billing
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and Minnesota statutes require school districts to seek reimbursement from private health insurers and public health insurers for the cost of health-related services included in the student’s IEP, IFSP or IIIP. Health-related services, as defined by IDEA, include supports such as:
  • Diagnosis, evaluation and occupational therapy
  • Speech, physical and occupational therapy
  • Mental health services
  • Audiology
  • Transportation
  • Health services such as nursing
The school district must have written consent to bill private and public health insurers. Parents can deny consent or withdraw consent at any time, and consent is valid for up to one year. Regardless if parents allow school districts to bill insurers, their child’s services will not change and will continue at no cost to the family. Private health insurers provide coverage through a parent’s employer or through a private plan. Public health insurance plans are offered to your child through a government program such as Medical Assistance. If parents give written consent for third party billing, the private insurer is considered the primary payer and is always billed first. School districts are responsible for any out-of-pocket expenses, such as co-pays. According to the Minnesota Department of Education, money from third party billing can be used for three things only:
  • The benefit of students with special needs in your district
  • To pay for the cost of doing third party billing
  • To get training and help increase the amount of third party billing

MORE INFORMATION

Third party billing: PACER fact sheet Minnesota Department of Education (MDE): Third Party Reimbursement

item.title: Behavioral Assessments & Supports
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
FUNCTIONAL BEHAVIOR ASSESSMENT (FBA)

If a student has a disability-related behavior that is negatively impacting their education, parents or staff can request a Functional Behavior Assessment (FBA). Behaviors are a form of communication and a FBA looks for the communicative intent behind the behavior. When the purpose is discovered, strategies can be put in place to help reduce an unwanted behavior. According to the Minnesota Department of Education, “Comprehensive behavior assessment and student-specific positive behavior interventions are critical for providing appropriate specialized services for students with disabilities and challenging behaviors.” The University of Minnesota has published a 70-page compilation of tips sheets to promote positive behavior: Introduction to Positive Ways of Intervening with Challenging Behavior. For more details on Functional Behavior Assessments, see PACER Center's Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports, Using a Functional Behavioral Assessment to Understand Behavior.

POSITIVE BEHAVIORAL INTERVENTIONS & SUPPORTS

Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports (PBIS) is a broad range of systematic and individualized strategies for achieving important social and learning outcomes while preventing problem behavior. (OSEIP Center on PBIS, 2010). You can learn more from Minnesota PBIS. The Minnesota Department of Education (MDE) shares information on how over 300 schools have successfully implemented PBIS and explains some of the key features.

item.title: 504 Plan
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
Section 504 is part of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, a civil rights law that prohibits discrimination based upon disability. Any program that receives federal funding must make their activities accessible to all individuals with disabilities. Section 504 is administered by the Office for Civil Rights (OCR). The U.S. Department of Education has no enforcement authority and no state or federal funding is available under Section 504. School districts must cover these costs. Parochial schools (or other schools) that do not receive federal funding are not required to comply with Section 504. Students with qualifying disabilities under Section 504 receive accommodations and modifications to allow them the opportunity to perform at the same level as their peers without disabilities. Federal law states that in order for a student to qualify under a 504 Plan, he/she must have a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activity. Having a medical diagnosis of a disability does not automatically qualify a student for a 504 Plan. Students that qualify for services under Section 504 receive accommodations and modifications that help them benefit from their educational program. Services are provided by regular education staff and help the student to remain in the least restrictive environment (LRE). Each school district must designate someone to coordinate compliance with Section 504. The requirements for a student to qualify for a 504 Plan are less restrictive than for a student to qualify for an Individualized Education Plan (IEP) under IDEA. A 504 Plan is an option for some students who do not qualify for IEP services, but still need some assistance to fully participate in school. If a student fails to qualify for special education and related services under IDEA, he/she may be referred for a 504 evaluation. Accommodations and modifications vary according to the unique needs of each student. Accommodations typically alter the condition of a test or instruction, but do not change the substance of the test or instruction. Accommodations are more about access. Modifications typically change the substance of the test or instruction. A modification can change the level of required performance or the information tested.1

EVALUATION PROCESS

  • A referral is made for an evaluation by a parent, school staff or service provider. Parents should make their request, in writing, to the school principal.
  • Parents must give written permission for the evaluation.
  • The evaluation is done by a multi-disciplinary team from the school district that is familiar with the student.
  • Information is gathered from a variety of sources in order to determine the areas in which a disability is suspected.
  • If it is determined that a student qualifies for services under Section 504, (having a disability that substantially limits a major life activity), a 504 Plan will be written.

WHAT’S INCLUDED IN A 504 PLAN?

  • The student’s disability and the resulting needs
  • Accommodations and/or modifications determined to be necessary as a result of the evaluation
  • The person responsible for providing the services
  • The case manager responsible for ensuring the 504 Plan is implemented
  • Description of the placement in the least restrictive environment

IDEA VS. 504: INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES EDUCATION ACT (IDEA) AND SECTION 504

IDEA: An education act that provides funding for special education and related services Section 504: A civil rights law prohibiting discrimination for people with disabilities IDEA: For students 3-21 who qualify for special education and related services Section 504: For any person who qualifies as having a disability as stated under Section 504 IDEA: A student’s disability falls under one of 13 areas of disability Section 504: Doesn’t use categories of disability; uses physical or mental disability as criteria IDEA: Disability must affect education to qualify for services Section 504: Qualifies if a disability limits one or more major life activities (not limited to education) IDEA: Students are served under special education 504 Plan: Students are served under regular education IDEA: A reevaluation is done at least every 3 years to determine if student still qualifies for services 504 PLAN: Student is reevaluated periodically IDEA: Guarantees a free appropriate public education (FAPE) 504 PLAN: Also guarantees a free and appropriate education IDEA: Students are served in the least restrictive environment (LRE) 504 PLAN: Students are also served in the least restrictive environment IDEA: A due process hearing is an option to resolve conflicts 504 PLAN: Conflict resolution is not detailed, uses a hearing officer appointed by school district IDEA: Stay Put available for discipline concerns 504 PLAN: Stay Put not mentioned IDEA: Federally funded program 504 PLAN: Funded by each school district

WHERE TO FILE A GRIEVANCE COMPLAINT

If a parent feels their child is being discriminated against by the school district or feel the school is not complying with a 504 Plan, they can file a complaint within 180 days to the Office of Civil Rights (OCR): Office of Civil Rights - Chicago U.S. Department of Education Citigroup Center 500 West Madison Street, Suite 1475 Chicago, IL 60661 Voice: 312-730-1560, 877-521-2172 Fax: 312-730-1576 TDD 312-730-1609 Source: 1 School Accommodation and Modification Ideas for Students who Receive Special Education Services. Retrieved April, 2017, from http://www.pacer.org/parent/php/PHP-c49a.pdf

item.title: Getting Organized
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded:
GETTING STARTED

Wait to sort through all that paperwork until you have a block of time to organize it. In the meantime, place all the information in one place – a box, a container, etc. This will help reduce the chance of misplacing an important document and will keep your home from being overrun by paper. Purchase a separate file cabinet or large container that will be used exclusively for your child’s paperwork and keep this information separate from the rest of the household documents. Office supply stores carry home-friendly systems to organize information within the cabinet or container. Get one that allows room for growth over time. A personal copier and fax machine is not necessary but can save time and trips to the local copy center. Keep a 3-ring binder with blank pages divided into categories: school, medical, government programs, etc. Use this as a phone log to keep track of conversations. Be sure to write down the date of the conversation and whom you spoke with along with important details of the call. A 3-ring binder will allow you to add extra sheets as needed. You can also include important email correspondence. It is so much more efficient to have all of this information in one place and not on little pieces of paper, on the backs of envelopes or on something that might be thrown away by mistake.

STAYING ORGANIZED

In the front of each section, list contact names along with mailing addresses, email addresses, and phone numbers. This will save valuable time and energy wasted tracking down this information when you need it. Don’t forget contact information for the pharmacy and other medical suppliers. Do not write on original documents – make a copy and jot down notes and other pertinent information on the copy. Label the copies with "original (date)" and "working copy (date)" so as to avoid confusion with multiple copies of the same document. If your child has multiple therapies or doctor visits scheduled, it is important to have a method of keeping track of them. It can be as simple as a wall calendar with times listed on it or a more sophisticated system for techno-savvy parents. Be aware of any cancellation policies medical providers may have to avoid unnecessary charges. Keep a journal for your child. Include information on their general disposition, illnesses, changes in mood, sleep, and behavioral concerns. For some children, keeping track of what they are eating is necessary. Over time, a journal may give valuable information in spotting patterns linked to changes in behavior. For example, you may see changes when school starts, at daylight savings time or during spring and fall allergy seasons.

POST A LIST OF EMERGENCY CONTACT INFORMATION IN A PROMINENT PLACE FOR CAREGIVERS

Having this information located in one convenient location could be invaluable in the event a caregiver needs to step in quickly to care for your child. This list should include:
  • Emergency numbers, including Poison Control
  • Your child’s primary doctor and dentist
  • Your preferred hospital
  • Information for family and friends who can help with your child in a crisis
  • A list of your child’s known allergies and other important health information
  • An Emergency Contact Sheet you can fill in and use can be found here.

WHAT TO PUT IN YOUR FILES

Medical
  • Copies of all medical records (letters, chart notes, test results) from your child’s medical providers. Be sure to request copies of these documents at every appointment. Because of HIPAA privacy laws, you may need to sign a release of information to get this information.
  • A list of all prescriptions and non-prescription medications and supplements your child is taking along with dosages.
  • Assemble a 3-ringer binder that includes copies of all medical records. Divide them by specialist or test (i.e. Neurologist, Endocrinology, and EEG’s) and organize them by date. Keep the originals in a safe place. For each appointment, copy pertinent information to give to the doctor for his/her records. If there is a lot of information to share, organizing them in a format similar to the way suggested above will help the doctor look through the information quickly and efficiently.
  • Medical insurance information, including information on in-network providers, co-pays, deductibles and contact information.
  • Explanation of Benefits (EOB) Forms – EOB Forms are sent by your child’s insurance providers and explain services provided, how much was charged, and the amount paid. EOB’s are not required by participating providers who receive full reimbursement directly from the insurer.
  • Copies of immunization records
  • Therapy progress reports
  • Journal articles or other information pertaining to your child’s disability. If your child has a rare or complex condition, this information can be helpful to share with medical providers.
Educational Keep copies of all Individualized Education Plans (IEP’s), 504 Plans, Evaluations, Progress Reports, Standardized Test Results and other pertinent correspondence with school staff. See the Education Section for more information on these documents. Periodically, visit the school and review your child’s educational records, called a cumulative file, to make sure they are accurate and current. You are entitled to view and have copies made of your child’s records; however there may be a charge. Government and Financial Depending on your child’s individual situation and programs they are utilizing, the documents you need to save will vary. Organize and store them by year and/or by program or agency. Guardianship and conservatorship reports need to be filed annually, so mark the date on your calendar. It is important to file these documents with the court on time, and the County does not send reminders when they are due. The forms need to be notarized. Your local bank or city office may notarize documents at no charge. Supplemental Security Income (SSI) Representative Payee Reports need to be filed annually. A form will be sent by the Social Security Administration asking for an accounting of how your child's benefits were spent. Save your receipts!

item.title: SEAC: Building Bridges to Better Education for Children with Disabilities
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: A Special Education Advisory Council, or SEAC, is a group of individuals devoted to bettering the education of students with disabilities by serving as an advisory body to their local district on matters of special education. The purpose of a SEAC is not to decide policy, but rather to support the district’s special education program and the students involved by sharing their experiences, providing the district with feedback on existing services, and offering advice on how to more effectively meet their needs in the future.Read more.

item.title: Kids Learn Best When They Want To Learn
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: When students can't see the point of learning – they almost certainly won't. Motivation is therefore very important for effective learning. If we can create an environment in which students want to learn, then we have done the hard part: the learning will flow quite naturally. Read more.

item.title: Tips for Starting the New School Year
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Learn ways to prepare your child and school staff, ideas on establishing routines, ways to organize paperwork, and how to get involved. Read more.

item.title: Transition
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: What does the word Transition mean in the world of special education? Read more.

item.title: Summary of Secondary Transition Services for Special Education Students in Washington County Schools
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: In late 2012, a questionnaire containing 8 questions about the content of Transition Programs was sent to each of the 10 school districts in Washington County. Read more.

item.title: Transition Planning -- It Takes a Village
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: There are two major turning points in the lives of school-aged children with disabilities and their families. The first one is when they enter the special education system. The second is when they leave it. Read more.

item.title: Speech and Language Therapy in a School Setting
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Teachers and parents share many concerns about children at school. My child has difficulty following directions. John can’t seem to clearly explain his ideas. Most people have trouble understanding Lydia’s speech. Charles stutters. Angela doesn’t know how to communicate in social situations and misinterprets social cues. Grace struggles with vocabulary. Jacob doesn’t understand abstract language including jokes. Alex’s grammar is poor. Read more.

item.title: Budget Stretchers
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: In today's economy, many of us need to budget money. This can be critically important for people with disabilities, especially those living on their own. People with disabilities have the highest rate of poverty of any minority group in the United States Read more.

item.title: Self-Advocacy – A Journey Through Life
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Too often, people forget how truly special they are. They forget how much they have to offer and all the stories they have to share and questioning their own worth, they hide their greatness from the rest of the world, but by becoming a self-advocate, an individual is able to overcome their self-doubt and show the world to all they are capable of. Self-advocacy is a journey that allows individuals to reach the peak of their potential, and with every step they take, they leave behind a lasting imprint of who they are and all they have done. Read more.

item.title: Surviving the Holidays With Your Sanity Intact
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Our families are far from typical. So why do we try to be that perfect “Norman Rockwell” family during holiday get-togethers? Tell yourself right now that you and your family are going to enjoy the holidays in your own way and at your own pace. Stop worrying about what others think and make the holidays meaningful for your children. Here are some holiday issues that might come up and some creative ideas to make it work for your family. Read more.

item.title: Person Centered Planning
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Person Centered Planning is a series of processes used to learn about people with intellectual or developmental disabilities and to help them plan for their future. By putting focus on the individual and what they want, Person Centered Planning gives individuals the chance to be heard and to organize their lives in a way that is concordant with their needs, likes, strengths, and desires. This technique not only enables them to live the lives of their choosing, but also provides them with the opportunity to Read more.

item.title: Granite House
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: It was a moment the Insley family would never forget, a precious memory engraved permanently in their hearts as a place of solace and peace they would return to many times in the difficult years to come. It was a moment of pure bliss as Aaron and his father Tom proudly stood atop the summit of Granite Peak, Montana, after conquering the 12,799 foot climb to the top, a feat Aaron’s older brother Richard had accomplished eight years earlier. It was a moment that would inspire them for the rest of their lives. Read more.

item.title: Helping Your Child With Special Needs To Be Independent
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Families of children with special needs may be overprotective, and often feel justified because of the challenges their children face. But children with special needs need to reach their personal best potential, and should be encouraged to be as independent as possible starting at an early age. Read more.

item.title: April is Autism Awareness Month! Autism: Improving Understanding in the Community
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Autism has practically become a household word in the last few years. We hear about it at school, in the media and out in the community. Someone you know is likely affected by an autism spectrum disorder (ASD), either themselves or someone in their family. But what is it like to have autism?Read more.

item.title: The Groove
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: One of the most interesting and consistent findings from the Adult Down Syndrome Center is the discovery that people with DS need sameness, repetition and order in their lives. We call this tendency the "groove" because thoughts and actions of people tend to follow fairly well worn paths, or grooves. Read more.

item.title: The Role of Grandparents
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Grandparents play a unique role and often share special relationships with their grandchildren. This relationship, however, can become more complicated when their grandchild has a disability. Read more.

item.title: Spotlight on Resources You Should Know About
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: ConnectWC provides information and links on a large variety of resources to help individuals with I/DD live full and productive lives. In the coming months, we will be highlighting a variety of these resources. Some you may have heard of and others may be new. Our hope is you will find some good information that you will find useful. Read more.

item.title: Holiday Tips and Strategies from ConnectWC
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: The following words of wisdom are from members of ConnectWC who have adolescent and young adult children with intellectual and developmental disabilities. They have developed strategies over the years to help the holidays go more smoothly Read more.

item.title: Self-Care When You're Caring for Others
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Good nutrition as a caregiver is nourishing to you on many levels. Eating healthy will not only help you cope better, it may also protect you and your family members from future health problems. Read more.

item.title: The Autism Society of Minnesota (AuSM)
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Autism is a complex developmental disability that is present from birth or very early in development. It affects essential human behaviors such as social interaction, the ability to communicate ideas and feelings, imagination, self-regulation, and the ability to establish relationships with others. Although precise neurobiological mechanisms have not yet been established, it is clear that this disability reflects the operation of factors in the developing brain.Read more.

item.title: Stop Running by Building Skills
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Nat runs to avoid work. Sherry runs when she wants attention. Mark runs whenever he can. They ran in the past and continue to run in spite of strategies created to stop the running. Sound familiar? Read more.

item.title: Meet The Arc
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: The Arc Greater Twin Cities and The Arc Minnesota are advocacy organizations that serve individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities, including those living in the Washington County area. Read more.

item.title: Surviving the Holidays
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: The holiday season is often challenging for most of us. For our family members with special needs, it is even more stressful. We need to employ all of our "social thinking skills" during this season Read more.

item.title: Smart Apps for People with Disabilities
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: In the world of developmental disabilities, smartphone and iPad apps have been life changing. They help users communicate and offer many therapeutic, educational and behavioral benefits. Read more.

item.title: Social Skills Learning on the 9th Planet
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: A family is hosting a friend for dinner. The child in the family watches as the friend reaches for a cookie and says, "You'd better not eat that or you'll gain more weight." Read more.

item.title: Election Day is Tuesday, November 4th
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: It is a fundamental right and responsibility of all Americans to vote, even in an 'off' year when there is no presidential race. Elected officials vote on crucial funding, services and supports for people with disabilities. Read more.

item.title: Visit With Elected Officials - March, 29, 2014
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: On Saturday, March 29, 2014, ConnectWC in partnership with The Arc Greater Twin Cities hosted A Visit With Your Elected Officials event at Family Means in Stillwater, Minnesota, to educate our legislators about disability issues. Read more.

item.title: The JacobLab Making Strides for ASD
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: There are currently no approved medications specific for social behaviors in autism. Recently, several investigational drugs are being studied because of their potential to improve social functioning and restrictive, repetitive behaviors in individuals with autism. Read more.

item.title: Therapeutic Riding: Seeing Disability Through a Thousand Pound Mirror
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Horses are often described as "thousand pound mirrors", capable of generating a reflection in which the riders are able to truly see themselves and develop a deeper understanding of who they are, how their mind works, how their body moves, and what they are capable of. Read more.

item.title: Nature Is the Ultimate Sensory Experience: A Pediatric Occupational Therapist Makes the Case for Nature Therapy
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: When I tell people I’m a pediatric occupational therapist and that I run nature programming, a look of confusion often crosses their face. “Huh?” they say. Or, “You’re a special needs camp?” Or, “I don’t get it. You’re going to do occupational therapy with our children?” Read more.

item.title: Music Therapy and Social Skills Development: From Isolation to Community
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Participating in music therapy and creating together fosters not only an awareness of one another but an appreciation and a sense of cohesion amongst the group as each individual has a unique musical contribution.Read more.

item.title: Problems with Pollen -- Reactions to pollen can impact learning and behavior
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Bursting tree buds are a happy harbinger of spring. But budding brings pollen and when pollen is plentiful, problems with attention, behavior, and mood are sure to follow for susceptible children. Read more.

item.title: Autism Spectrum Disorders and Comorbidity
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: “Melanie looks sad, depressed and doesn’t have any close friends. Why does Charlie always defy me? Jack’s teacher thinks he has ADHD, how can I tell? Sam said he doesn’t care if he lives anymore. Carrie worries about everything…she has strange obsessions and compulsions. Our adolescent son has been diagnosed with four or five different mental disorders, which one is right?” Read more.

item.title: What is the Gut-Brain Connection?
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Have you ever become sick to your stomach after hearing bad news? Or maybe you felt foggy headed or became anxious after eating a certain food? The brain and the "gut" are intimately connected with each other, and this link occurs very early in our lives. Read more.

item.title: Aquatic Body Work
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Water has positive associations for many of us: the relaxation of a hot shower at the end of a long day, the giggles of a young child being bathed in a warm tub, or even the nurturing water-like atmosphere we all experienced back in the womb. This innate healing quality of water is a unique and powerful feature of aquatic body work. Read more.

item.title: Therapeutic Riding: Seeing Disability Through a Thousand Pound Mirror
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Horses are often described as "thousand pound mirrors", capable of generating a reflection in which the riders are able to truly see themselves and develop a deeper understanding of who they are, Read more.

item.title: Yes You Can Learn Karate!
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Ages 6-60+ can do Karate. There are huge benefits to learning this sport. And just like school, when the teaching is customized and adapted to meet a person’s needs, success happens. Read more.

item.title: Let’s Go Fishing!
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Our Mission: The Stillwater Area Chapter of Let’s Go Fishing is committed to its mission of providing no-cost fishing and boating excursions in the Stillwater/St. Croix Valley Area. We serve seniors (55+), persons with physical or developmental disabilities, all military members and the families of those deployed, veterans and intergenerational youth. Read more.

item.title: The Yoga Bridge -- An Integrated Approach for Special Learners
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Our bodies are meant to function as a whole, integrated unit. Whatever we do in one area affects other areas. Can we improve thinking just by moving our bodies? Read more.

item.title: Epilepsy and Sports
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: With the increasing awareness of the physical and mental benefits of regular exercise, many hopeful athletes with epilepsy are wondering if they can play sports, including contact sports. Read more.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Migrating To a New Website!
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.excerpt:encoded: This is an amazing time. It is the best of times. It has only just begun. Join us as we present our brand new website to the world!

item.title: TEST TESTIMONIAL
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: This is the best wordpress theme eva!!!

item.title: Dance Break
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: You can dance if you want to. You can leave your friends behind. BECAUSE YOUR FRIENDS DON'T DANCE AND IF THEY DON'T DANCE THEN THEY'RE NO FRIENDS OF MINE...
item.excerpt:encoded: For the sake of clean code, we shall drop our computers and S A F E T Y D A N C E. See you all there.

item.title: Exercising with a Disability
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Have you ever thought about why exercise is important for you and your loved ones? Have you ever thought about exercise being even more important for your loved one with a disability? Read more.

item.title: Roots, Wings and Guardianship
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Helping our children to feel both grounded and independent is a fundamental tenet of parenting. So we give them roots and wings by imparting skills and values. We harp on them to buckle their seatbelts, eat their veggies, and treat others with respect. After we’ve counseled them on how to do their homework and manage money and relationships, we guide them toward a college or a career path. All with the expectation that when they reach adulthood, we can step away as they launch their independent lives. Except when they have special needs. Read more.

item.title: Opening Doors In Washington County
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Midwest Special Services, Inc. (MSS) announces the opening of a new Day Training & Habilitation program in Oakdale. Read more.

item.title: Tony Stories – Humorous Reflections of a Parent Raising a Son with Autism
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: I’m so happy as I’m sitting at the graduation ceremony, but then I make the mistake of looking over at my dad and he’s getting teary eyed. I know he’s thinking that my mom should be here for this moment, but she passed away three years earlier. Nobody loved a good Tony story more than my mom. That’s when I lose it and the tears start to come and I cry and cry through the whole ceremony. Of course, we are sitting in the second row, so the faculty is sitting directly in front of us. The principal, the superintendent, the teachers are all there. I smile at them as the tears continue to stream down my face, slightly embarrassed, but I try to make the best of it. Even my daughter Tara, who is 15 and at the age where she thinks her mom is a total dork, tries to comfort me. She puts her arm around me and smiles. Tony is graduating today and we’re here to celebrate this wonderful boy. Read more.

item.title: 2016 Summer Camp Guide for Campers With Disabilities
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Summer camps offer great opportunities for socialization, independence, exercise and fun! ConnectWC has compiled a list of Minnesota outdoor summer camps designed for campers with disabilities as well as camps that integrate campers of all abilities. To help in the search, we've included a few websites that allow searches by various criteria to help find the perfect camp!Read more.

item.title: The Community Create Club – Building Something Beautiful
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: The Community Create Club is a unique and heart-filled therapeutic program dedicated to promoting creative expression for teens and adults of all abilities. As a canvas for creativity in their community, this program offers a variety of artistic outlets such as music, art, and movement through which participants are able to express their thoughts and feelings while also improving their physical, mental, emotional, and social well-being. Read more.

item.title: Top Ten Summer Activities for Kids with Special Needs
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Summer can be a challenging time for children with special needs and their parents. Many families face a decrease in school and therapeutic hours. This may leave parents with extra time to fill during the day. Read more.

item.title: Having Fun in the Winter Months
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: In our continuing series on Resources You Should Know About, our focus this month is on activities to enjoy during our cold Minnesota winter. Getting out of the house, getting exercise and spending time with friends are important for everyone. Here are a few ideas for activities to do while we wait for spring to arrive! Read more.

item.title: Fun Things To Do This Summer - updated for 2016!
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: School is out for the summer. Now what do we do? Check out this reference guide compiled by ConnectWC of fun things to do with your child and the entire family. Post it on your fridge to refer to all summer long! Read more.

item.title: Valley Friendship Club -- Making Friends Having Fun!
item.dc:creator: connectwc
item.content:encoded: Making Friends Having Fun! This is Valley Friendship Club's motto! FUN for all participants: children, teens, young adults, families and volunteers. Valley Friendship Club (VFC) is also about making connections -- Read more.
